The 90 Percent Rule

Recently, a colleague and I worked to select twenty-four people.  

We chose from a pool of almost one hundred applicants.  

We created a set of minimum criteria, like “Can attend every class.”  

Then, we identified ideal attributes, such as “Is ready for a life-changing experience.”  

We scored each candidate on a 1 to 10 scale.  

The 9s and 10s were obviously in.  

Anyone under a 7 was automatically out.  

I had the unenviable task of evaluating the in-between candidates.  

These were the 7s and 8s.  

As I struggled, I had a thought.  

If something is just good enough, it should be a no.  

This realization was liberating.  

You can think of this as the 90 Percent Rule.  

You can apply it to almost every decision or dilemma.  

As you evaluate an option, think about the most important criterion.  

Then, give the option a score between 0 and 100.  

If you rate it lower than 90 percent, change the rating to 0.  

Simply reject it.  

This way, you avoid getting caught up in indecision.  

You also avoid getting stuck with the 60s or 70s.  

Think about how you’d feel if you scored a 65 on a test.  

Why choose to feel that way about an important choice?  

Mastering this Essentialist skill requires vigilance.  

We must acknowledge the reality of trade-offs.  

Applying selective criteria is a trade-off.  

Sometimes you must turn down a good option.  

Have faith that the perfect option will come along.  

Sometimes it will, and sometimes it won’t.  

The key is that applying selective criteria forces you to choose.  

You decide which perfect option to wait for.  

Do not let others or the universe choose for you.  

Like any Essentialist skill, it requires decisions by design.  

The benefits of this ultraselective approach are clear.  

When our selection criteria are too broad, we commit to too many options.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The 90 Percent Rule encourages making decisions by rejecting any option that scores below 90 percent, promoting a disciplined approach to selecting only the best choices in life.
